The treatise says:
Next, by how many kinds of bases should the Dharma body be known as the basis?
In brief, by three bases:
First, by the various bases of the buddhas' abodes.
Here there are two verses:
The five kinds of joy realized by the buddhas are all due to the realization of their own realm,
Apart from joy, it is all due to the non-realization of this, therefore those who seek joy should realize it equally.
Due to being able to be immeasurable and accomplishing things, the Dharma, taste, meaning, and virtues are all perfectly complete,
Obtaining the most supreme joy without fault, because the buddhas see it as always inexhaustible.
Second, the various enjoyment bodies are based on the maturation of all bodhisattvas.
Third, the various transformation bodies are based on the maturation of Å›rÄvakas and others.
The commentary says:
By how many kinds of bases should the support be known? This question asks how many kinds of dharmas the Dharma body is based on.
Briefly by three bases means that the support of immeasurable merits is now explained in brief by only three bases.
As for due to various Buddha abodes, the Dharma body attained by the TathÄgatas serves as the basis for the various celestial abodes, holy abodes, and Brahma abodes in which they dwell.
Among the celestial abodes, the TathÄgatas mostly dwell in the fourth dhyÄna;
among the holy abodes, the TathÄgatas mostly dwell in the door of liberation of emptiness;
among the Brahma abodes, they mostly dwell in compassion.

Thus, the various superior abodes of the TathÄgatas surpass those of the Å›rÄvakas and others. In order to show that the nirvÄá¹‡a attained by the TathÄgatas surpasses the nirvÄá¹‡a attained by the Å›rÄvakas and others, it is said that the Buddhas attain the five kinds of joy, etc.
Attaining one's own realm means attaining one's own Dharma realm.
Because one cultivates and realizes this, it is called equal attainment.
As for free from joy, it means that the TathÄgatas, having attained their own Dharma realm, abide in the five joys.
The Å›rÄvakas and others attain [nirvÄá¹‡a] as if severing the head, which is permanently extinguished, far removed from nirvÄá¹‡a.
Those who seek joy should realize this equality means that bodhisattvas diligently seek five kinds of joy and should correctly realize this true dharma realm.

The sought-after supreme joy is next explained as being due to immeasurable ability and accomplishing tasks, etc. The differences in joy are due to distinctions in causes.
Ability refers to capability.
Immeasurable means surpassing immeasurable Ganges sands.
The capability possessed by all buddhas and tathÄgatas is the same in relying on the dharma body, and all are mixed and equal without distinction.
By seeing this immeasurable ability, one gives rise to great joy.

And has the meaning of collection. Tasks refer to what is to be done. All the beneficial and joyful tasks for sentient beings are established without error according to their abilities in the three vehicles, etc.
Accomplishing means accomplishing. For immeasurable time, these tasks are performed without obstruction.
By seeing the capability and the tasks to be done, which are also immeasurable, one gives rise to great joy.
As for the flavor of the Dharma, it refers to the unsurpassed flavor of the Dharma such as the sutras, and the flavor of the principle obtained through realizing the truth.
As for the perfection of meaning, it refers to the fact that the meaning expressed by the Dharma such as the sutras is all perfectly obtained, because it appears in accordance with one's own wishes.

As for the perfection of virtue, it refers to the perfection of virtues such as spiritual powers, because seeing the flavor of the Dharma is also immeasurable, seeing the perfection of meaning is also immeasurable, and seeing the perfection of virtue is also immeasurable, one gives rise to great joy.
There are also those who say that meaning refers to nirvana, and virtue refers to the virtues that arise in accordance with one's wishes. Because both are perfect, one gives rise to great joy.

Obtaining the most supreme joy without fault, because the Buddhas always see it without end, it means that the Tathagatas see that the one flavor of suchness within their own bodies can give rise to immeasurable joy, and although they enter nirvana it is also always inexhaustible. Therefore, it is most supreme and without fault.

Because it transcends the three realms, it is called supreme. Because both the obstacle of the passions and the obstacle to that which is to be known, along with their propensities, are eternally eliminated, it is called free of error.
As a result of being the support of the body of enjoyment for the various hosts, etc., means that because the Dharma body is the dominant condition for its appearance, it is said to be its support.
It is not like the relationship of the sun and its light.
The meaning of being the support of the transformation body is also like this.

As for the phrase â€œfor the most part,â€ this refers to bodhisattvas of the stage of action in faith, because those of inferior faith and understanding, such as Å›rÄvakas, etc., even though they see the Buddhaâ€™s body, are not yet mature. The same is true of beginners in the bodhisattva path.

The Treatise says that
it should be understood that the Dharma body is held by how many qualities of a Buddha?
In brief, by six kinds.
First, as a result of purification, that is, as a result of the transmutation of the store consciousness, one acquires the Dharma body.
Second, by retribution, that is, by transforming the physical faculties and attaining the cognition of retribution.
Third, by abiding, that is, by transforming the abodes of desire, etc., and attaining the abiding of immeasurable cognition.
Fourth, by mastery, that is, by transforming the mastery of various appropriated actions and attaining the mastery of cognition of unobstructed spiritual powers in all worlds.

Fifth, by speech, that is, by transforming the idle discourse of seeing, hearing, cognizing, and knowing, and attaining the mastery of cognition that delights the minds of all beings and speaks eloquently.
Sixth, by rescue, that is, by transforming the rescue from all calamities and faults, and attaining the cognition that rescues all beings from all calamities and faults.
It should be known that the Dharma body is subsumed by these six kinds of Buddha-dharmas that have been explained.
The commentary says:ğŸ”½In terms of subsuming by intrinsic nature, it manifests the subsumption of the intrinsic nature of the Dharma body.
By purity means subsuming by the pure Buddha-dharmas, because the essence of the Dharma body is pure.
Who is purified? Who is the one who turns and attains purity?
In order to answer this question, it is said, â€œBecause the Älaya consciousness is turned, the Dharma body is attained.â€

It is like the worldâ€™s atagarda medicine, which can transform poison into non-poison. Therefore it is called turning.
Because of retribution means that the Buddhaâ€™s teachings are held by the retribution body.
The essence of the Dharma body turns the material sense organs means that it turns the eyes and other material sense organs.
Attaining the knowledge of retribution means that what is turned and abandoned is retribution, and therefore it is metaphorically said that the attainment of turning is also retribution.
Just as the sense organs that were attained in the past are now attained as good knowledge, they are metaphorically called retribution.
Because of abiding means that the essence of the Dharma body is held by the Buddhaâ€™s teachings that are abiding.

Turning away from desire and so forth means equally taking away resolve and so forth. By turning away from them, one realizes the knowledge of extinguishing all sentient beings' calamities and afflictions.
By mastery means the nature of the Dharma body is subsumed by the Buddha-dharmas.
Receiving and upholding the activities means the activities of merchants, farmers, kings, and so forth in the world. By turning away from them, one realizes unobstructed spiritual powers and mastery.
By speech means the nature of the Dharma body is subsumed by the Buddha-dharmas.

Calamities and so forth means the worries and sufferings produced by kings, families, and so forth in the world, which can be alleviated by the power of relatives or the power of wealth and treasures.

By transforming this, one realizes the wondrous cognition that can eliminate all calamities and faults of all sentient beings. One transforms and abandons these six worldly dharmas and transforms and attains these six buddha dharmas.
The treatise says:
The Dharma body of all buddhas, should it be said to be different or non-different?
Because there is no difference in support, intention, and activity, it should be said to be non-different;
Because immeasurable supported bodies manifest realization, it should be said to be different.
Just as it is said that the Dharma body of buddhas, the enjoyment body is also like this. Because there is no difference in intention and activity, it should be said to be non-different;
Not because there is no difference in support. Because immeasurable differences in support transform.
It should be known that the transformation body is like the enjoyment body explained.
The commentary says:ğŸ”½The Dharma body of all buddhas is without difference because there is no difference in support, intention, and activity.
Because the suchness of all buddhas is without difference, the support is without difference.
All are the same in their intention to benefit and gladden all sentient beings, and therefore their intentions are the same and not different.

All are the same in their superiority in benefiting others, and therefore their actions are the same and not different, because they perform various actions such as manifesting perfect enlightenment and parinirvÄá¹‡a.

It is said that they are different because they manifest perfect enlightenment in innumerable bodies, because Bodhisattvas manifest the attainment of Buddhahood in innumerable individual bodies, and they are not without differences, as was extensively explained above.

As it is said of the Dharma body, so it is also with the enjoyment body. This is said to be the same in intention and action, but it is not said that the support is without distinction, because the innumerable distinctions in support evolve.
That is to say, in all separate worlds, the Buddha lands, assemblies, names, body sizes, marks and embellishments, enjoyment of the Dharma, etc. of the Buddhas are not the same.
It should be understood that the transformation bodies of the Buddhas are also like this.
The Treatise says:
It should be understood that the Dharma body is associated with how many qualities?

That is, it is associated with the qualities such as the four immeasurables, liberations, spheres of mastery, spheres of totality, absence of conflict, cognition of the aspiration, four unobstructed abilities, six supernormal knowledges, thirty-two major marks, eighty minor marks, four kinds of purity of all aspects, ten powers, four kinds of fearlessness, three kinds of unguardedness, three establishments of mindfulness, eradication of habitual tendencies, unforgettableness, great compassion, eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, cognition of all aspects, and so forth.
The commentary says:
Here it clearly explains the pure and superior qualities possessed in common by the Buddhas, World-Honored Ones, and the Å›rÄvakas and others.
Most pure means that these qualities arise in the body through the complete severance of the afflictions and the obstructions to that which is to be known.
It should be understood that the expression most pure applies to each and every quality.
The four immeasurables are the immeasurable compassion, joy, and equanimity that take immeasurable sentient beings as their objects.
As for liberation, it refers to the eight liberations, namely, having form, contemplating various forms, and so forth.
As for the spheres of mastery, there are eight spheres of mastery.
As for the spheres of totality, there are ten spheres of totality.
As for the absence of conflict and the knowledge of the aspiration, there are no further distinctions.

As for the four unobstructed abilities, they are the unobstructed ability regarding phenomena, the unobstructed ability regarding meaning, the unobstructed ability regarding language, and the unobstructed ability regarding elocution.
As for the six supernormal powers, they are the supernormal power of spiritual penetrations as the first, and the knowledge of the destruction of the contaminants as the last.
As for the thirty-two major marks of a great man, they are the mark of the excellent wheel, the mark of the hands and feet being soft and tender, and so forth.
As for the eighty minor marks, they are the mark of the nose being prominent and straight, and so forth.
As for the four kinds of purity of all aspects, they are the purity of the basis, the purity of the object, the purity of the mind, and the purity of cognition.

As for the ten powers, they are the power of knowledge of proper and improper conditions, the power of knowledge of the ripening of karma, the power of knowledge of meditative absorptions, liberations, concentrations, and attainments, the power of knowledge of the superior and inferior faculties of beings, the power of knowledge of various resolves, the power of knowledge of various realms, the power of knowledge of the paths that lead everywhere, the power of knowledge of recollection of past abodes, the power of knowledge of death and rebirth, and the power of knowledge of the exhaustion of contaminations.
The four forms of fearlessness are as follows: The Buddha, the World-Honored One, himself declares:
I am a true, perfect, and complete enlightenment.
If there is an objection, saying:
You are not perfectly enlightened with regard to such and such dharmas.
I do not see any basis for that objection, this is the first fearlessness.
Moreover, he declares:
I am a true one whose contaminations are exhausted.
If there is an objection, saying:
Your contaminations have not been exhausted in such and such ways.
I do not see any basis for that objection, this is the second fearlessness.
Moreover, he declares:
I teach the path that leads to deliverance for my disciples.
If there is an objection, saying:
Cultivating such a path is not the correct way out of suffering.
I see no basis for this objection, which is my third fearlessness.
Moreover, I declare with sincerity:
I tell my disciples that defiled [actions] that are obstacles will definitely be obstacles.
If someone objects, saying:
Even if one is defiled by those [actions], they cannot be obstacles.
I see no basis for this objection, which is my fourth fearlessness.

In these four [fearlessnesses], one should explain in detail that one sees no basis for the objections, and thus attains great peace of mind. Because one attains peace of mind, one is completely fearless.

The three non-protections refer to all the physical actions of the Tathagatas, which are pure and manifest, and there is no impure physical action that they need to protect by concealing for fear of others knowing. This is called the first non-protection.
As explained for physical actions, verbal actions and mental actions are also explained in the same way, and these are the three non-protections.

As for the three foundations of mindfulness, when the TathÄgata expounds the true Dharma, some disciples listen respectfully, abide in a mind of obedience, diligently practice, and follow the Dharma according to the Dharma. The TathÄgata has no delight or joy in them and his mind does not leap up.

Some disciples do not give rise to respect, the opposite of the above, and so on at length. The TathÄgata does not give rise to anger or resentment towards them, nor does he give rise to intolerance, nor does he not maintain them.

Some disciples give rise to respect and also do not respect, and so on at length. The TathÄgata's mind towards them is without duality, that is, he is neither delighted nor angry or resentful. He abides in the wonderful equanimity that pervades all of them.
As for eradicating habitual tendencies, it means forever eradicating the activities that resemble afflictions even though there are no afflictions, such as leaping and so on.
As for the Dharma of non-forgetfulness, it means being mindful and aware of the matters that benefit and delight sentient beings without exceeding the proper time.
As for great compassion, it means the great meaning of the intention to benefit and gladden sentient beings, which will be explained later.
The eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha are the meaning of not being the same as, which is the meaning of not being shared.
That is to say, the tathÄgatas are without error or loss.

It is like the arhats, who although they have exhausted the contaminants, when they go out to the cities and towns to beg for food, sometimes they encounter bad elephants, bad horses, bad oxen, bad dogs, and so forth, and they stay together with them; sometimes they step on thorns and bad snakes, and their feet are bitten; sometimes they enter such houses and speak improper words with women; sometimes they abandon the good roads in the forests and fields and take the bad roads; sometimes they stay together with enemies, thieves, lions, fierce beasts, and other people's wives;
such errors and losses of the arhats, the buddhas are all without.
Also, the tathÄgatas are without abrupt or violent sounds.

For example, an arhat may at one time be wandering in the forest and lose his way, or enter an empty house and shout loudly, or due to the fault of uncontaminated latent tendencies, he may gather his lips and show his teeth while laughing loudly;
such sudden and violent sounds of the arhats, the Buddhas are all without.
Moreover, the Tathagatas have no forgetfulness.
For example, an arhat may have uncontaminated forgetfulness of things done long ago or words spoken long ago;
the Buddhas are all without this.
Moreover, the Tathagatas have no various thoughts.
For example, an arhat may give rise to thoughts of extreme aversion towards the remaining birth and death, and thoughts of extreme quiescence towards the nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder;
the TathÄgata has no differentiated thoughts towards the remaining birth and death and the nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, abiding in supreme equanimity.
Moreover, the Tathagatas have no undetermined mind.
For example, an arhat may enter samÄdhi with a concentrated mind, but emerge from it with an undetermined mind;
The TathÄgata is always in a state of concentration without any lack of mental focus.
Moreover, the TathÄgata does not abandon anything without having examined it.
Unlike arhats who, without having examined the various matters of benefit and joy for sentient beings with wisdom, simply abandon them;
the TathÄgata does not have this kind of abandonment without examination.
Moreover, the TathÄgata does not have the six kinds of loss such as desire.

Unlike arhats who have the loss of not yet attaining complete purification of the afflictive obstructions, that is, the loss of aspiration, the loss of zeal, the loss of mindfulness, the loss of concentration, the loss of wisdom, and the loss of liberation;
the Buddhas do not have these six kinds of loss.
Moreover, the TathÄgata's physical, verbal, and mental actions are guided by wisdom and turn according to wisdom.
Unlike arhats whose physical actions sometimes function well and sometimes function indeterminately, and whose verbal and mental actions should be understood in the same way;
the TathÄgata's three actions are guided by wisdom and turn according to wisdom, so they are never indeterminate.
Because they are produced by wisdom, they are called preceded by wisdom. Because they accompany wisdom, they are called turning with wisdom.
Moreover, the Tathagatas, in regard to the objects of the three times, have unobstructed and unattached knowledge and vision.

Unlike arhats, who, in regard to the events of the three times, are not able to understand them immediately upon arousing the mind, so their knowledge and vision are said to be attached. Because they are not able to understand everything, their knowledge and vision are said to be obstructed.
The Tathagatas, in regard to those events of the three times, immediately understand all objects upon arousing the mind. Therefore their knowledge and vision are unattached and unobstructed.
For this reason, each of these eighteen is called a unique quality of the Buddha.
The subtle wisdom of all aspects means being well able to understand all aggregates, realms, and sense bases.
All aspects, etc. means being equal to the other immeasurable qualities associated with the Dharma body.
The treatise says:
There are many verses on this.
The commentary says:
In this Dharma body, which is able to rely on the uncommon merits, it concludes the meaning of the verses and analyzes and reveals them.
The treatise states:

The commentary states:
In this verse, it reveals the four immeasurables.

The commentary says:
This verse shows that the absence of conflict has the nature of conventional knowledge.

The treatise says:

The commentary says:
This verse shows the four kinds of unobstructed understanding.
What is called the basis refers to the teachings, namely the sutras and so forth.
What is called what is based on refers to the meaning that is expressed.
These two kinds are both called what is spoken, because they are the objects of activity.
What is called wisdom is that which is able to speak, because it is what is produced by the doer and the tools of action.
Unimpeded wisdom means the wisdom that is unobstructed in this regard.
Always speaking well means that by possessing the four kinds of unobstructed understanding, one is always able to speak well.
If unobstructed enlightened wisdom regarding the basis is called the unobstructedness of dharmas, it is because there is no obstruction regarding the different aspects of dharmas.

If unobstructed enlightened wisdom regarding what is based on the basis is called the unobstructedness of meaning, it is because there is no obstruction regarding the specific and general characteristics of all dharmas, or because there is no obstruction regarding the different meanings and intentions of the various dharmas.

If unobstructed enlightened wisdom regarding words is called the unobstructedness of expression, it is because there is no obstruction regarding the various words and phrases of different lands, which are spoken according to the different thoughts of each person, or because there is no obstruction regarding the explanation of the words and phrases of the various dharmas.

If unobstructed enlightened wisdom regarding the knowledge that analyzes the various dharmas is called the unobstructedness of eloquence, it is because there is no obstruction regarding the knowledge that is able to analyze the various dharmas.
The treatise states:
For the sake of those sentient beings, he manifests knowledge, speech, and action,
Coming and going, and liberation. I pay homage to the one who skillfully teaches.
The commentary explains:
This verse displays the six kinds of spiritual powers.
For those sentient beings is a general term.
Good teaching is said to be possessed by each one.
Good means wonderful.
Teaching means words.
In order to make them progress, speaking wonderful words is called good teaching.
Good teaching that is manifested is the supernormal power of mind-reading, going to the place where one should be transformed, manifesting great spiritual powers, and well teaching them.
Good teaching that is known through words is the supernormal power of the divine ear, listening to meaningful words and all sounds from afar, and teaching the Dharma according to their needs.

Good teaching that is known through actions is the supernormal power of knowing others' minds, knowing the superiority and inferiority of minds, and well teaching them.ğŸ”½Good teaching that is known through past lives is the supernormal power of recollecting past lives, understanding the past, and well teaching them.
Good teaching that is known through future lives is the supernormal power of knowing death and rebirth, understanding the future, and well teaching them.
Knowing the skillful teachings for attaining liberation refers to the supernormal knowledge of the extinction of contaminants, knowing the skillful teachings for eliminating afflictions.
The treatise states:
All sentient beings who see the Honored One know him to be a true good person,
Having a deep faith upon merely seeing him, I pay homage to the one who guides and inspires.
The commentary explains:

This verse shows that the major and minor marks are the basis for manifesting the major and minor marks of the Dharma body. Therefore, in terms of the major and minor marks, one pays homage to the Dharma body.

All sentient beings who see the Honored One know him to be a true good person means that all worlds, by seeing the World-Honored One endowed with the major and minor marks, all know him to be a great good person.
Sentient beings comprehensively includes those who are able to receive teachings at that time and in the future.

Having a deep faith upon merely seeing him means that upon merely seeing the World-Honored One endowed with the major and minor marks, one immediately has a deep and pure faith, knowing him to be the one who skillfully guides and inspires the world.
The treatise states:

Mastery of samÄdhi and wisdom, following realization, I pay homage.
The commentary states:
This verse shows the four kinds of purity of all characteristics.

Accepting, upholding, and abandoning shows the purity of the basis. Relying on meditative concentration, according to one's wishes, one can freely accept, uphold, and abandon long or short [life spans] in one's own body.
Manifesting transformations and changing shows the purity of the object.
Transforming into various previously non-existent forms is called manifesting transformations.
Changing various previously existent forms into gold, silver, and so forth is called changing.
